story.title: The Story
story.paragraph1: Two years ago, Ria was burnt out from her tech career in Silicon Valley, coming out of a difficult relationship, and struggling with mental health issues. Running became her way out.
story.paragraph2: Within a year, she went from struggling to finish a half marathon to setting ultramarathon records on world-renowned routes.
story.bullet1: The Via Francigena: 1,014 km in 21 days
story.bullet2: The Camino de Santiago: 780 km in 12 days
story.highlight: She asked herself: what is the most impossible thing I could attempt? The answer: running 20,000 kilometers from Vladivostok to Lisbon, retracing the ancient Silk Road.

cost.question: How much does it cost?
cost.answer: The full expedition budget is approximately €250,000. This breaks down into: Vehicle (~€35K), Logistics & visas (~€50K), Day-to-day expenses (~€55K), Crew support (~€60K), Gear (~€5K), Documentary (~€35K), and Miscellaneous (~€10K). The minimum viable budget with 1 vehicle and 2 crew is ~€95K.

perKm.question: How is €5 per kilometer calculated?
perKm.answer: €100K is the bare minimum of what it costs to make the project happen. It would not include compensation for the crew that spends time on this project. Everybody would be pure volunteers.

goalNotMet.question: What if the goal isn't met?
goalNotMet.answer: The run starts May 1st, 2026 regardless. If fully funded, Ria runs with a support crew and vehicle. If not, she runs solo and unsupported until enough funds have been raised.

unusedFunds.question: What happens to unused funds?
unusedFunds.answer: All unused funds will be returned to supporters proportionally. Full transparency on spending will be provided throughout the journey.
